The {+city’s-city’s / cities|499} name is derived from {+Kenova's-Kenova’s’ / Kenova|499} three bordering states: Kentucky, Ohio, and West Virginia.

Kenova was also home to the recently demolished Ceredo-Kenova High School, winner of 12 {+state-state / State|411} football championships. Ceredo-Kenova High School graduated several well-known {+athletes,-athlete’s, / athletes,|501} musicians, and entrepreneurs: Pittsburg Pirate baseball player, Donny Robinson, Grammy Award winning Christian musician, Michael W. Smith, and CEO of Intuit, Brad Smith, to name just a few.

In 1970 Kenova made national headlines when a plane carrying the Marshall {+University-university / University|411} football team, {+coaches-coach’s, / coaches,|501} and community leaders crashed into a hillside while approaching Tri-State Airport, located near the city limits. The movie "We Are Marshall," starring Matthew McConaughey, is based on the story of how the University overcame the tragedy and rebuilt the football program where {+-(notables / notable’s)|228} Chad Pennington, Byron Leftwich, and Randy Moss played. Several scenes from the movie were actually filmed in Kenova.
63.title: Kenova, West Virginia

7.passage:
Every Friday, Nasreddin would arrive at the market with a donkey to sell. He always sold the donkey very cheaply, at a far lower cost than any of the other donkeys that were for sale.

Finally, one of the merchants confronted Nasreddin. "I do not understand how it is possible, {+please-pleas|200} explain yourself!" he exclaimed. "With threats of violence, I compel the farmers who are my tenants to give me food for my donkeys at no cost. My workers are {+poor-pour|202} slaves and I pay them no wages for taking care of the donkeys. I {+lose-loose|268} no profit anywhere. That means I am able to sell my donkeys at the lowest possible price, but even {+then-than|272} you sell your donkeys for even less. {+It's-Its|262} unreasonable! How can that be?"

Nasreddin smiled at the merchant and explained, {+"You're-"Your|284} stealing the food and the labor. I, however, am just stealing the donkeys!
7.title: Nasreddin and the Thieves (Mythology)

8.passage:
On July 16th, 1969, hundreds of people traveled to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to watch the Launch of the Apollo 11 rocket. Speakers announced, “You {+may-can / may|119} not approach the launch site without permission.” Nine and a half years ago, President John F. Kennedy promised we would land a man on the Moon in the next 10 years. Today was the last chance America had to keep its promise. NASA knew they {+must-must / should|120} launch the rocket now, or they would run out of time. The crew asked Mission Control if they {+may-may / can|119} begin the countdown to launch. It was a perfect day for flying, so NASA knew there {+should-should / must|120} not be any problems.

After a rocket leaves Earth, there is nothing else Mission Control {+can-may / can|119} do, so the launch is always tense. Once the rocket was close to the Moon, Mission Control told the crew they {+must-must / should|120} circle the moon once, because that was the only way to slow down. NASA suggested that they {+should-should / must|120} try to find some good rocks to bring back.

Two of the crew members, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, launched a smaller ship from the Apollo 11 rocket, and landed on the Moon. When Neil Armstrong first stepped out of the ship he said, “That's one small step for a man, and one giant leap for mankind.”
8.title: One Giant Leap for Mankind (History)

9.passage:
The ancient Hawaiian people were not as technologically advanced as other cultures of the time. However, by the time western civilization began communicating with the Hawaiian people, they had already developed a rich cultural heritage. They went about their lives by surviving off of the land, following strict social rules, and {+respecting-respected|251} their aumakuas, or "family gods." Unlike more powerful deities, such as Pele, the fiery goddess of volcanoes, aumakuas interacted specifically with individual families as spiritual guides. They were known for appearing in peoples' dreams, {+save-saving|252} people from harm, and bringing about good fortune to people in need.

Like the spirit guides of other religions, aumakuas were said to be able to shape-shift. They could appear as a shark lurking on the ocean floor, or a hawk circling the skies. However, they were said to make themselves known easily to anyone who worshipped them. Out of respect for these spirit guides, the Hawaiian people payed tribute to them, asked for their guidance, and {+considered-consider|249} them to be family.
9.title: Nā ʻaumākua (History)
